doc.after: In 1907, the Chulkhurst Charity was amalgamated with other local charities with similar purposes, to form the Biddenden Consolidated Charity,[10] still functioning as a registered charity.[43] The Bread and Cheese Lands were sold for housing,[note 11] expanding the charity significantly to provide Biddenden pensioners and widows with bread, cheese, and tea at Easter, a cash payment at Christmas, and distribute Biddenden cakes.[21] (During the food rationing of the 1940s and early 1950s, the cheese was replaced by cocoa.[44] Distribution of cheese resumed in 1951.[45]) A wrought iron village sign showing the Biddenden Maids was erected on Biddenden village green in the 1920s.[21]
